metadata.h1: Audit using Machine Learning algorithm: A Financial Data Science use case
metadata.description: Use case of KNN Machine learning algorithm in finance. How simple Machine learning can generate scalable efficiencies in Audit and help reduce costs.

all_paragraphs: World of Data Science is full of wonders (except Unicorns!). It is everywhere in one way or the other with applications in health sciences, space exploration, image recognition , robotics, fraud detection etc. If you have ever watched something on Netflix or Prime, there are high chances that you have been exposed to the amazing movie recommender algorithms!
How we can employ ML techniques in a typical internal audit function to reduce false negatives and increase efficiency. Side effects: Cost reduction.
Finance is no different and we have been seeing a massive shift of organisations to application of advanced data science techniques for insights generation, forecasting, budgeting and fraud risk.
While I was researching on the use case of ML on a day to day audit, being a finance professional, one very real world problem we all face is that “what is different from norm”?

Imagine you have 1,600 transactions (or purchase invoices) where each transaction represents the ‘Quantity purchased’ (Volume) and ‘Amount’ paid for that quantity. To identify any outliers (i.e. transactions not following a normal pattern), in a typical audit environment, we would go in and try to extract a random sample from the population and then hope our ‘random’ sampling detects any such anomaly. This is sometimes both time consuming and counter-productive since we have a risk of missing out actual outlier not getting picked up by our sample and hence reporting a false negative. This can have detrimental impact on both cost and efficiency of the audit function.

So I have tried to employee an ML algorithm (KNN, which is explained further down) to address the above and automate the anomaly detection. This algorithm is using both Volume and Amount features from the invoice and calculating the outliers in the set of 1,600 such invoices.

Now good algorithm or code is as good as the story we tell. So before I go to nitty-gritty of the codes, below is a one page Executive summary or an elevator speech that can be shared with our business stakeholders:
Please keep reading below if you want to know how the model is built.

A package in Python that is specifically used for outlier detection modelling is called PyOD. This package (which I installed using pip install pyod) offers a variety of algorithms to detect outliers and is pretty easy to implement. In this article I will however restrict myself to use case of one proximity-based model known as KNN or K-Nearest Neighbour from this module. KNN is a mathematical model that measures the distance to its nearest Kth neighbour and identifies outlier in the data based on that distance. This is a classification algorithm that classifies the outliers as a binary outcome of ‘1’ and ‘0’ or say ‘Yes’ or ‘No’.

The above demonstrates a very simplistic example of Machine Learning use case in finance and audit environment. There are definitely number of factors and use of multiple models that we need to consider in a real world problem but in the interest of article’s length I have restricted it to KNN only.
